title: New E. coli Outbreak: Check Your Fridge for These Carrots
author: Lisa O'Mary

content: Nov. 18, 2024 – An E. coli bacteria outbreak traced to organic carrots has hospitalized 15 people and is now linked to the death of one person in California.

In total, 39 people have been sickened, according to the CDC . The carrots were sold nationwide, and illnesses have spanned 18 states coast to coast, with eight people sickened in Washington state, five people in Minnesota, and five people in New York.

The carrots were sold from Aug. 14 to Oct. 23. Recalled products include more than a dozen brand names for various sizes of packages of baby carrots and of whole organic carrots. The brand names include 365, Full Circle, Good & Gather, GreenWise, Nature’s Promise, and others. The carrots were sold at a variety of stores nationwide, including Trader Joe’s and Wegmans.

The FDA said its investigation is still ongoing. Meanwhile, health officials are urging people to check their refrigerators for the carrots. Baby carrot packages have best-if-used-by dates between Sept. 11 and Nov. 12. Whole organic carrot packages don’t have best-if-used-by dates printed on them.

content_blocks.text: Nov. 18, 2024 – An E. coli bacteria outbreak traced to organic carrots has hospitalized 15 people and is now linked to the death of one person in California.

In total, 39 people have been sickened, according to the CDC . The carrots were sold nationwide, and illnesses have spanned 18 states coast to coast, with eight people sickened in Washington state, five people in Minnesota, and five people in New York.

The carrots were sold from Aug. 14 to Oct. 23. Recalled products include more than a dozen brand names for various sizes of packages of baby carrots and of whole organic carrots. The brand names include 365, Full Circle, Good & Gather, GreenWise, Nature’s Promise, and others. The carrots were sold at a variety of stores nationwide, including Trader Joe’s and Wegmans.

The FDA said its investigation is still ongoing. Meanwhile, health officials are urging people to check their refrigerators for the carrots. Baby carrot packages have best-if-used-by dates between Sept. 11 and Nov. 12. Whole organic carrot packages don’t have best-if-used-by dates printed on them.

content: The most recent reported illness began around Oct. 27, although the first case stretches back to the first week of September. More illnesses may still be under investigation since it can take three to four weeks for scientists to link an illness to the outbreak.

This latest outbreak involves a specific strain of E. coli bacteria called O121. It produces a toxin called Shiga, and symptoms may include severe stomach cramps, diarrhea that is often bloody, and vomiting. Symptoms typically start within three to four days of swallowing the bacteria. While most people recover in a few days without treatment, there is a risk of developing dangerous kidney problems.

“The implicated farms are out of production,” stated a news release on the website of Grimmway Farms, the company that sells the carrots. The company’s recall notice indicates that its recalled carrots most likely have been pulled from store shelves, but people should check their refrigerators at home.
“Carrots on store shelves right now are likely not affected,” the recall notice stated. “If you have any recalled carrots in your home, throw them out or return them to the store.”

sources: FDA: “Outbreak Investigation of E. coli O121:H19: Organic Carrots (November 2024).”
CDC: “Outbreak Investigation of E. coli O121:H19: Organic Carrots (November 2024),” “CDC warns of new E. coli outbreak linked to organic carrots.”
Grimmway Farms: “Grimmway Farms Recalls Organic Whole and Select Organic Baby Carrots That May be in Consumers’ Homes Due to Potential E. Coli Contamination.”
meta_description: Recalled carrots sold at stores nationwide, including Trader Joe’s and Wegmans, now linked to one death and 39 illnesses.
